intro: Diphasiastrum carolinum, commonly known as the Carolina clubmoss, is a small evergreen fern-like plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Lycopodiaceae and is characterized by its compact, needle-like leaves arranged in whorls around the stem. The plant produces two types of spore-bearing structures—microsporangia and megasporangia—hence its scientific name. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in shaded, woodland environments. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is an important component of certain forest ecosystems.
